narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot of really useful vocabulary and grammar related to different social issues. After the course (and probably with a lot more review), I would feel comfortable engaging in a conversation about issues in the news in a more nuanced way. I especially appreciated learning the small differences in tone and usage of certain words that initially seem like synonyms. Overall, the course has improved my reading and writing skills immensely... although my speaking fluency has declined a little with the movement to only 3 class meetings a week.

My Chinese improved greatly, specifically my tones. I really appreciated the emphasis on good pronunciation, and how Zhan Laoshi helped us each fill in the gaps in our knowledge and perfect our communication skills.
I got better at speaking Chinese
Deepened not only my knowledge of the Chinese language but also understanding of the culture.
I gained a greater mastery of the Chinese language.
Definitely improved Chinese ability by learning newer grammar structures and vocabulary.
I greatly increased my conversational Chinese ability and reading/essay writing skills
Discussion in Chinese of different topics

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths: very comprehensive vocabulary and grammar, although it did feel like I was drinking out of a water hose and I would frequently fall behind in learning new words. The sheer exposure to different vocabulary and topics was very useful though and mildly entertaining when I would recognize more words from class when watching Chinese tv shows! Weaknesses: this is mostly due to the course design and I'm not sure if it could be changed, but I felt like I was less engaged with class because I would only need to speak maybe 2 or 3 times per session due to the number of students. Sometimes this was actually nice as it took the pressure off on days when I was less familiar with the new vocabulary, however it could be interesting if the class sometimes incorporated "lesson leaders" for a given topic and have them moderate a discussion? Though that may also be way too much work for third year students with a lot more on their plates...

This was a great course! It was incredibly organized, Zhan Laoshi was great at encouraging class engagement, and there was a strong emphasis on learning all the vocab and grammar thoroughly. Overall, the class environment was very fun and productive.

Strengths: Professor Chan was a delight, full of energy during every class and very available for office hours. She spoke really fast which improved my listening comprehension. Zoom Chinese class wasn't ideal but it was what we got.

Weaknesses: the textbook. I didn't like the textbook's format (no easy-to-use table of contents, no way to listen to the readings), sometimes there were misprints (with tones, or mixing up simplified and traditional characters), and the material was sometimes a bit weird or dated. Also, 4:30 MWF class is simply not the move -- though I liked my professor a lot, that was a low-energy time of day (especially Friday at 4:30).
The only weakness is that it is difficult to practice talking with the zoom classes, but overall a very engaging class.
The course was well taught and formatted for online learning, and even though it was a language class, I still felt engaged and able to practice the language.
Don't think there's any way to improve much--the class seemed pretty efficient as is.

Chan Laoshi's teaching was exceptional. She was friendly, thorough, and made the class engaging every day. I sometimes wished we had more time for each class because we would have to run late or speed up to cover all the material.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the course overall was nicely formatted for COVID-19 circumstances, although I think that enabling the chat function so you could message more than just the teacher could have been a helpful tool. Perhaps it could have been used to engage more students to respond to questions or provide thoughts while other students spoke, instead of just waiting for your 2-3 times to speak per class. I also think it can be useful to see what clarification questions other students may be asking, and a helpful hint from a classmate through direct message is always nice in a foreign language class.
Zhan Laoshi was good at getting people to talk and engage even over zoom. The breakout rooms were especially useful, because they gave us extra time to practice speaking.

I'd recommend that Chinese teachers ask all students to stay unmuted the whole class period. It's really annoying when a teacher has to interrupt people saying "you're muted, you're muted" because it interrupts the flow of class. Also, I'd like to have more opportunities to do short on-paper writing assignments so I don't totally forget how to write characters.
Homework format was very successful, but class discussions were difficult to maintain in whole-class zoom format.
My class was real small so I really think meeting in person could've been possible. Languages are super hard to learn over the internet.
Discussions over Zoom were difficult. Chan Laoshi would typically have to call on students to spark discussion. I don't think anything would improve this aspect of the virtual class.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course to another student, especially if they are already comfortable with conversing about basic topics and have their basic sentence structures down. From there, this class will provide many useful vocabularies that will take their Chinese to the next level. If you have a fairly heavy schedule and are not as comfortable, I'm not sure if I would recommend taking it if you are GPA conscious because there are many homework assignments of varying difficulties. Some weeks I would be scoring 90% and up... and others were straight 70% rates just because the content of listening comprehension or class texts were much more difficult.
Yes. This was a great course-- the workload is manageable, the class environment is fun, but you still learn a lot and get the chance to really develop your comprehension, writing, and speaking.
Yes
Yes, very interesting content used to learn the language as well as fun classes.
I would recommend this course to any student who wishes to pursue Chinese at an advanced level.
Absolutely--I really think the Yale Chinese department is superb.

I would absolutely recommend this course. Though the workload is somewhat challenging, I felt like my Chinese ability improved substantially over the term. Non-native Chinese speakers often seem to plateau at a high level and this course did a great job helping push through that challenge.
